docs.title: KSA Modding Wiki (Unofficial)
docs.text:
Welcome to the unofficial Kitten Space Agency (KSA) Modding Wiki.

This site aims to become the primary reference for creating, maintaining, and debugging mods for KSA.

Unofficial project

This wiki is a community-driven, unofficial resource. It is not affiliated with or endorsed by the KSA developers. All trademarks and copyrights belong to their respective owners.

docs.title: What you'll find here
docs.text:
• Getting Started – set up your tools and create your first simple mod.
  • Fundamentals – understand how KSA stores data, assets, and physics information.
  • Mod Types – parts, visuals, audio, environments, scripting/plugins, and more.
  • Pipelines & Tools – recommended workflows and tools for different types of content.
  • Reference – detailed documentation for config keys, formats, and engine behavior.
  • Advanced & Internals – reverse engineering notes, save formats, and experimental features.
  • Tutorials & Guides – step-by-step walkthroughs from beginner to advanced topics.
  • Troubleshooting – common issues, log locations, and debugging strategies.

docs.title: Audience
docs.text:
This wiki targets:

  • Players who want to create their first simple mod.
  • Experienced modders who want deep, technical information.
  • Tool authors who want to integrate with or extend KSA's modding ecosystem.

docs.title: Version and accuracy
docs.text:
KSA is under active development, and modding capabilities may change quickly.

Each page should clearly indicate which game build or version it was last tested against. If you spot anything outdated, please open an issue or pull request in the GitHub repository.

docs.title: Experimental and Unsupported Features
docs.text:
Some modding techniques may rely on behaviors or interfaces that are:

  • Undocumented
  • Unstable
  • Known to change between builds

Use this page to collect such experiments, and clearly label them as:

  • Experimental
  • Use at your own risk
  • Likely to break between versions

docs.title: Reverse Engineering Notes
docs.text:
This section is for advanced users interested in understanding KSA internals beyond the officially documented APIs.

Important guidelines:

  • Respect the game's EULA and local laws.
  • Avoid distributing proprietary game code or assets.
  • Focus on documentation and analysis, not leaks.

Example topics:

  • Observed data structures in memory or save files.
  • Hypotheses about how certain systems are implemented.
  • Tools and workflows used to inspect or debug behavior.

docs.title: Save File Structure
docs.text:
As the save format becomes better understood or documented, this page should describe:

  • File locations and naming patterns.
  • High-level structure (e.g. JSON, binary blobs, nested sections).
  • Key entities: vessels, celestial bodies, missions, player state, etc.
  • Versioning within the save format.

docs.title: Coordinates and Units
docs.text:
Because KSA is a realistic spaceflight simulator, units and coordinate systems matter a lot.

This page documents:

  • The base unit system
  • Coordinate conventions
  • Reference frames
  • Special considerations for orbital mechanics

docs.title: Base Units
docs.text:
KSA uses a standard physics unit system:

  • Length: meters
  • Time: seconds
  • Mass: kilograms

All position, velocity, acceleration, and force values throughout the simulation are expressed using these base units. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

docs.title: Handedness
docs.text: All coordinate frames in KSA are right-handed. This applies universally—global, local, orbital, and body-fixed frames. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

docs.title: Vector Naming
docs.text:
Vectors are suffixed with the frame in which they are expressed: :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

  • positionCce — position in Celestial-Centered Ecliptic
  • velocityCcf — velocity in Celestial-Centered, Celestial-Fixed

docs.title: Rotation Naming
docs.text:
Frame rotations use the notation X2Y to denote a passive rotation taking vectors from frame X into frame Y. Examples: :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

  • cci2Ccf — inertial → celestial-fixed
  • orb2Cce — orbital → ecliptic

Active vector rotations are also suffixed:

  • jointAngleBody — rotation expressed in the vehicle’s body frame

docs.title: Inertial vs Non-Inertial Frames
docs.text:
• Inertial frames are non-accelerating and non-rotating; ideal for describing motion.
  • Non-inertial frames rotate or accelerate, producing fictitious forces (centrifugal, Coriolis, etc.). These include frames fixed to rotating planets or thrusting vehicles. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

docs.title: Reference Frames
docs.text: Below is a summary of all major coordinate frames used in the simulation.

docs.title: ECL — Ecliptic Frame
docs.text:
The global “world” frame used for rendering and for comparing orientations throughout the system. Identical to CCE and CCI when centered on the sun. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

  • Type: Inertial
  • Origin: Center of the solar system
  • X: Direction of periapsis for a zero-inclination/zero-argument solar orbit
  • Y: Completes the frame
  • Z: Up direction; perpendicular to ecliptic

docs.title: CCF — Celestial-Centered, Celestial-Fixed Frame
docs.text:
A surface-fixed rotating frame used for surface-relative calculations. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

  • Type: Non-inertial
  • Origin: Celestial center
  • X: Equator–prime meridian intersection
  • Y: Completes the frame
  • Z: Celestial north pole

docs.title: CCI — Celestial-Centered Inertial Frame
docs.text:
Used for orbital simulation around a celestial. Axes remain inertially fixed with respect to the ecliptic. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

  • Type: Inertial
  • Origin: Celestial center
  • X: Periapsis direction for zero-inclination orbits
  • Y: Completes the frame
  • Z: Celestial rotation axis

docs.title: CCE — Celestial-Centered Ecliptic Frame
docs.text:
Shares the celestial’s origin but uses global ecliptic axes. Useful for cross-celestial orientation comparisons. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

  • Type: Inertial
  • Origin: Celestial center
  • X/Y/Z: Identical to ECL axes

docs.title: ORB — Orbit Frame (Perifocal)
docs.text:
Defines the orbital plane of a spacecraft or celestial. Commonly used in Keplerian element conversions. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

  • Type: Inertial
  • Origin: Orbital focus (celestial center)
  • X: Toward periapsis
  • Y: Completes the frame
  • Z: Orbital angular momentum direction

docs.title: LVLH — Local Vertical / Local Horizontal
docs.text:
Useful for spacecraft attitude control. Provides intuitive axes (down, forward, etc.) for a vehicle in orbit. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

  • Type: Non-inertial
  • Origin: Celestial center
  • Z: Toward celestial center
  • Y: Opposite orbital angular momentum
  • X: Completes the frame

docs.title: VLF — Velocity Frame
docs.text:
Designed for maneuver planning using prograde/normal/radial axes. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

  • Type: Non-inertial
  • Origin: Celestial center
  • X: Prograde
  • Y: Normal
  • Z: Radial (completes the frame)

docs.title: BODY — Vehicle Body Frame
docs.text:
Fixed to the spacecraft geometry. Defines roll, pitch, and yaw axes. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

  • Type: Non-inertial
  • Origin: Vehicle structural origin
  • X: Forward / nose direction (roll axis)
  • Y: Pitch axis
  • Z: Downward / yaw axis

docs.title: AERO — Aerodynamic Frame
docs.text:
Used for computing aerodynamic forces. Aligns X with the relative wind direction. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

  • Type: Non-inertial
  • Origin: Object center of mass
  • X: Into the relative wind (drag axis)
  • Y: Completes the frame
  • Z: Toward parent celestial

docs.title: Data Formats Overview
docs.text:
KSA uses various file formats for configuration, assets, and state.

Common categories include (but are not limited to):

  • Config files – human-readable formats such as JSON, YAML, or custom text formats.
  • Meshes and models – typically imported from DCC tools like Blender via supported formats.
  • Textures – standard image formats or engine-specific compressed textures.
  • Save files – persistent state data; may be more complex or binary.

As the game and modding tools evolve, this page should be updated with:

  • Exact file extensions
  • Example snippets
  • Notes about versioning and compatibility

docs.title: Game Directories and File Layout
docs.text:
Understanding how KSA organizes its files is essential for modding safely and effectively.

This page will document:

  • The installation directory layout.
  • Where user data, saves, and mods live.
  • Which folders are safe to modify directly (if any) and which should be left alone.

docs.title: Your First Simple Mod
docs.text:
This tutorial walks you through the rough structure of creating a very simple mod, such as tweaking a configuration value or swapping a texture.

This page is intended as a gentle introduction; more advanced topics are covered in later sections.

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial you should:

  • Understand where basic game data lives.
  • Create a small change that you can enable/disable easily.
  • Know where to look for errors when something goes wrong.

docs.title: Installing Tools
docs.text: This page describes the basic tools you'll likely want when creating mods for KSA.

docs.title: Essentials
docs.text:
• A text editor (VS Code, Sublime Text, etc.) for editing config files and scripts.
  • A file archiver/browser for inspecting game data if needed.
  • The KSA game itself, installed in a location where you can access its files.

docs.title: Nice-to-have tools
docs.text:
Depending on what you're working on, you might want:

  • A 3D modeling tool (e.g. Blender) for parts and environment assets.
  • An image editor (e.g. GIMP, Krita, Photoshop) for textures.
  • Diff/merge tools to compare config files across versions.

Later pages will provide more specific recommendations for each type of content.

docs.title: Getting Started with KSA Modding
docs.text: This section gives you a high-level overview of what modding in KSA looks like and what you need before creating your first mod.

docs.title: What you can mod
docs.text:
KSA is designed as a modding-first game. Over time, it will support (or already supports):

  • New or modified parts (engines, tanks, structural elements, etc.).
  • Visual changes such as textures, skyboxes, and effects.
  • Audio replacements or additions.
  • Gameplay changes, balancing, and configuration tweaks.
  • Potential scripting/plugins and deeper integrations.

The details depend on the current game build. Always check the version information on each page.

docs.title: Modding workflow (high-level)
docs.text:
Most mods will follow this general pattern:

  1. Identify what you want to change or add.
  2. Locate the relevant config files and assets.
  3. Create or modify files in a structure the game can load.
  4. Test your changes in-game, inspect logs, and iterate.

Later pages go into each of these steps in depth.

docs.title: Documentation Style Guide
docs.text: To keep this wiki consistent and readable, contributors should follow these guidelines.

docs.title: General tone
docs.text:
• Be clear and concise.
  • Use neutral, technical language.
  • Prefer examples and concrete details where possible.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
• Start pages with a short summary of what they cover.
  • Use headings in order (#, ##, ###, ...) without skipping levels.
  • Use bullet points and tables where they improve readability.

docs.title: Code and config snippets
docs.text:
• Use fenced code blocks with an appropriate language tag (for syntax highlighting where useful).
  • Keep examples minimal but complete enough to be copy-pasteable.
  • Indicate which KSA version the example has been tested against.

docs.title: Versioning and Compatibility Policy
docs.text:
KSA is under active development, and modding behavior may change between builds.

This wiki aims to:

  • Label pages with the KSA build or version they were last verified against.
  • Document breaking changes between game versions where possible.
  • Preserve old information when it remains useful for older builds, while clearly marking it as such.

Contributors are encouraged to:

  • Note the game version used when testing examples.
  • Update version notes when confirming behavior in newer builds.
  • Avoid removing historical information without a good reason.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
If and when KSA exposes scripting or plugin APIs, this section will describe:

  • Supported languages or runtimes.
  • Plugin structure and loading.
  • Safety/sandboxing considerations.
  • Example "hello world" scripts and plugin templates.

docs.title: Part Mods
docs.text:
Part mods add or modify physical components used in rockets, spacecraft, or infrastructure.

Topics to cover here:

  • How parts are defined in config files.
  • How parts reference meshes, colliders, textures, and audio.
  • Mass, thrust, ISP, and other physical parameters.
  • Attachment points and orientation conventions.
  • Best practices for performance and balance.

docs.title: Modeling Pipeline
docs.text:
This page documents a recommended pipeline for creating and importing 3D models into KSA.

Common steps include:

  1. Modeling and UV unwrapping in a DCC tool (e.g. Blender).
  2. Exporting in a supported format.
  3. Converting or importing into the game's asset pipeline.
  4. Hooking up meshes, colliders, and materials in configs.

docs.title: Texture Pipeline
docs.text:
Here you'll define how to create, compress, and ship textures for KSA.

Topics:

  • Recommended resolutions and aspect ratios.
  • File formats and compression.
  • Color space (linear vs sRGB).
  • Normal, roughness, emission, and other special maps.

docs.title: Tools Index
docs.text:
This page lists community and official tools that help with KSA modding.

For each tool, include:

  • Name and short description.
  • Author and repository link.
  • Supported KSA versions.
  • Typical use cases and limitations.

Note: This wiki does not need to host all tools; linking to their official repositories is usually preferred.

docs.title: Config Keys Overview
docs.text:
This section is the heart of the reference part of the wiki: a structured list of configuration keys the game understands.

Suggested structure:

  • General config concepts.
  • Part-related keys (mass, thrust, resources, etc.).
  • Environment-related keys (gravity, atmosphere, etc.).
  • Visual/audio-related keys.
  • Scripting/plugin-related keys (if applicable).

Each key should ideally have:

  • Name
  • Type (string, number, enum, etc.)
  • Valid range or options
  • Default value (if any)
  • Example usage
  • Version notes

docs.title: Physics and Performance
docs.text:
This page gathers information about how KSA's physics behave and how mods can impact performance.

Ideas to cover:

  • Time step, solver characteristics, and precision.
  • Limits (e.g. maximum recommended part counts, collider complexity).
  • Performance tips for content creators:
  • LODs and mesh density.
  • Texture sizes and compression.
  • Efficient use of particle effects and lights.

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text:
This page lists common modding-related errors and how to fix them.

For each error or symptom, include:

  • The error message or behavior.
  • Likely causes.
  • Steps to diagnose and resolve the issue.
  • Notes about specific KSA versions if relevant.

docs.title: Logs and Debugging
docs.text:
Knowing how to find and read KSA's logs is essential for modding.

Topics:

  • Log file locations on each platform.
  • Log verbosity and debug modes (if available).
  • Searching logs for common problems.
  • Techniques for instrumenting your mods for better diagnostics.

docs.title: Tutorials and Guides
docs.text:
This section collects step-by-step guides for KSA modding, from beginner-friendly to advanced.

Example topics:

  • Creating your first part from scratch.
  • Making a visual-only mod.
  • Adding sound effects to an engine.
  • Building and packaging a complex mod for release.

Each tutorial should clearly state:

  • Target skill level.
  • Required tools.
  • Tested KSA build/version.
  • Estimated time to complete.
